ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I think the lectures are great and that Brad and Luke both did a great job of facilitating discussion. I'm a bit more ambivalent towards the clinical project aspect. I feel like it can be really hit or miss and you can end up doing a project that doesn't really apply any of the concepts learned in class.

a bit more direct instruction at the beginning would be helpful to frame the discussion-based course. myproject was not very exciting - just a lot of grunt work not really a deliverable i can put on my resume like i was hoping.
I was an auditor, and do not feel like I can comment on questions 1-12.
Client-based work is always useful, and this class offers a weekly opportunity to meet new and interesting speakers. Great Class.

One great field trip with Alex Barrett to do some land surveying and title work, but I really wish therehad been more. That one was so helpful. Also, by the way, Brad Gentry is the best instructor at this school.
This was an awesome class. The only change I would make in the future is to have the class in a room where the tables/desks face each other. I think it would facilitate discussions a little better.
Brad is very responsive to student interests and connects them with visiting practictioners
Great class. I audited and found the speaker series very valuable and informative.
Brad is an excellent professor, possibly the best FES has to offer.

this class took me outside my comfort zone as far as subject material and theme. i'm so glad it was structured and run by brad, whose systematic methods made the class feel like it was progressing in an ordered way. there was a decent balance of the practical and the theoretical here.
A great class, and so helpful in its practical application!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Getting so much exposure to so many leaders in the conservation field.
The in-class discussions with classmates.
really interesting speakers! the focus on the changing conservation movement!
The guest lecturers and field trips, definitely.
Listening toa different speaker each week was great. Students were exposed to many interesting perspectives and a wide array of great topics.
Weekly lectures from a variety of speakers of different backgrounds. Opportunity to have dinner with the speakers also great feature of the class.
I really enjoyed having a different guest speaker in class each week. The diversity of perspectives was fascinating and useful, even if i didn't always love the speakers.
Class discussions. Q&As with speakers. Luke's emails titled "Strategies."
The client project, and class discussions prior to the guest speakers.
Excellent line-up of speakers
Discussions during first half of class.
the group discussions between people taking the class. these were exciting, by far the most exciting part of the class, and i wish they weren't so controlled. some of the speakers were great.
The wide variety of speakers, and the chance to use the knowledge we were gaining in a very applied way.
The variety of speakers, topics and points of view. Also the freedom to respond to the readings on our own terms, not according to a pre-determined list of questions.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The "doing deals" curriculum in the first half of the semester seemed somewhat repetitive. Could have moved faster through that section, and/or done more applied lessons (simulations, etc.) instead of just readings and lectures.

expand a bit more beyond easements. smaller dinners were really nice. this may be a bit hand-holdy, but maybe advice on how to make the most of the dinners? have fun vs. focus conversation on work? some speakers clearly wanted to do one or the other.

I thought that the course felt a bit scattered. I wish that the clinic component and classroom component were separated; I often felt like I didn't really have enough time/energy to fully discuss or process either.In theory, it would be great to see this split into two courses (perhaps two 2-credit courses; everyone takes the lecture part of the course, but the clinic could be optional)--one could focus more heavily on guest speakers (and also lectures from Gentry--it would be great to have had some of those) and a second component would involve the clinic.As it was, it seemed that we had a high enough classroom obligations (tons of readings and weekly reading responses) that I often felt my clinic project suffered.I basically took this class because of the guest lecturers (I didn't have time in my schedule to audit without credit), but was pretty ambivalent on the clinic component of my semester. As a student who has taken several clinic classes--I find that I'm overwhelmingly ambivalent on them; for every clinic project that's great and useful, there seem to be two more with a disinterested client or uncertain project. As such, I would have liked to have been able to gain the knowledge from the classroom portion of the class without having had to take another clinic.

While I appreciated the notion of client-based work, I wish that we had more frequent interactions with our clients. But of course that varies from case to case. Maybe there's some way to ensure interactions?
One meeting with Brad and project group would have been good to keep us on track and bring up new ideas/questions/strategies.

the class should spend more time on discussions, of the readings, of our projects, of concepts, and of actual strategies. the visitors, though very interesting, often rehashed much of the same material or ideas, or they remained in very general overviews. sometimes i felt they were not worth having interrupted the group discussions. perhaps the class can be split into two days?

Sometime the readings seemed to be too much--especially in light of the fact that we were all also working on clinical projects. I found myself sometimes having to prioritize readings over clinical work. I think the readins could be fewer, since a lot of them were kind of repetitive, especially in the latter part of the semester. (The readings for the first several weeks were all helpful.)
While it is useful to learn from each other's experience, I often felt the first part of the class where we shared our clinical work was too long.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Really good format with the class discussion for the first half and guest speaker for the 2nd half.
Strong and effective relationship â we'd discuss last week's lecture at the start of every class, then have another lecture afterwards. Effective structure.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I'm interested in all elements of land conservation--and going into this class I knew almost nothing about private conservation.
I took this course so that I could have at least basic familiarity with land conservation issues should I end up working for a natural resource management organization.

Unlike many of the students in the class, I may never work for a land trust, or have to structure a land deal. Still, I expected that the legal and financial strategies we discussed would be applicable to other environmental arenas.
A course that is a building block for later in my career
it expanded what i think about when it comes to environment and professions within it. gave me new language and ways of thinking about management.
My field is agriculture, and land conservation, as I now realize, is a vital part of agricultural preservation.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: i wanted to learn about how to create sustainable working landscapes on private land. different approaches to engaging different populations.
See above.
See above.
See above.
Brad's reputation as an academic-practictioner and desire for exposure to conversation finance.
Relevance to my field of research.
see above
In order to understand how land conservation fit into a broader picture of preserving small-scale agriculture.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes!
Yes.
Yes â I learned a variety of techniques for approaching land conversation, and I do think this skillset will help me think about other environmental challenges in a different, more pragmatic way.
YES!
Yes
Yes.
Yes, absolutely.
yes
Yes, they did, especially because I was able to work with a group for my clinical project specifically on issues of agricultural land.
It not only met my expectations, but exceeded them. This is an extremely useful class for future land conservation practitioners in a variety of contexts.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Worked with an SOM student, and it was great â we shared the burden, contributed different sets of knowledge, and enjoyed each other's company.
Formed a new, meaningful relationship with a classmate while diving deep into one area of student.

advantages: were able to cover more ground, my partner brought knowledge and skills i don't have to the table, we were able to cooperate to really figure out what our project was about when our instructions were vague or strange.disadvantages: were few (for once). i'd say the biggest one was that because we were covering so much ground, there was some distance between what either of us thought we were doing. we had to check in frequently to recalibrate.
Definitely made the clinical project manageable. It would have been overwhelming otherwise.

There were no disadvantages from my perspective. The advantage was that my partner and I have different professional backgrounds, interests and skill sets which all contributed to producing a well rounded document. My partner and I got along very well and produced a document that our clients are extremely happy with.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: go for it! keep the readings on file and engage with the speakers outside of class if you like!
Take the course if you're interested in land conservation or private conservation, but be aware that it's a fairly high work load.

I am commenting as an auditor only: This is a superb course to audit with few requirements and a wonderful opportunity to get exposure to the meat of land conservation and many influential players in the field. Even amidst a busy schedule I looked forward to the talk each week. I was unable to attend any of the evening dinners that were held with the speakers, but they were also great opportunities for students.
Make sure to have frequent interactions with your client, and make sure you're both very clear about what it is you're trying to achieve.
Take it! Brad is great and the class is super well organized. Learned a lot.
Carve out a regular time for the readings
Good class! Great networking opportunity!
Take any class with Brad Gentry that you can. He is calm, experienced, professional, engaged, supportive, and he cares about his students' success.
take it. remember that your group project will take over your life for a little while. be sure the one you choose is something you can justify to yourself.

Definitely take it! It's a great class, and Brad's a great professor. It really gives you a chance to learn about land conservation and to apply this knowledge through the clinical projects. Really valuable.

This is an excellent class that introduces you to innovative approaches to land conservation while also providing a solid framework for the skill sets involved in acquiring and managing a conservation easement.
